<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_digest_auth_get_username:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN char *
MHD_digest_auth_get_username (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params;
  char *username;
  size_t buf_size;
  enum MHD_DigestAuthUsernameType uname_type;

  params = MHD_get_rq_dauth_params_ (connection);
  if (NULL == params)
    return NULL;

  uname_type = get_rq_uname_type (params);

  if ( (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_STANDARD != uname_type) &&
       (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_EXTENDED != uname_type) )
    return NULL;

  buf_size = get_rq_unames_size (params, uname_type);

  mhd_assert (0 != buf_size);

  username = (char *) MHD_calloc_ (1, buf_size);
  if (NULL == username)
    return NULL;

  if (1)
  {
    struct MHD_DigestAuthUsernameInfo uname_strct;
    size_t used;

    memset (&uname_strct, 0, sizeof(uname_strct));

    used = get_rq_uname (params, uname_type, &uname_strct,
                         (uint8_t *) username, buf_size);
    if (uname_type != uname_strct.uname_type)
    { /* Broken encoding for extended notation */
      free (username);
      return NULL;
    }
    (void) used; /* Mute compiler warning for non-debug builds */
    mhd_assert (buf_size >= used);
  }

  return username;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
used = get_rq_uname (params, uname_type, &uname_strct,
                         (uint8_t *) username, buf_size);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment itself does not call any <string.h> functions and passes an allocated buffer and its size (buf_size) to get_rq_uname, so there is no direct evidence of a Rule 21.17 violation in this fragment. However a violation can occur if the callee misbehaves: for example, if get_rq_unames_size returns a value smaller than the actual required number of bytes (or omits the NUL), or if get_rq_uname ignores the supplied buf_size and uses unsafe string functions (e.g. strcpy/strcat/memcpy) to write more than buf_size bytes into username, then that would cause out‑of‑bounds accesses and violate Rule 21.17. Note also that the code only uses mhd_assert to check used <= buf_size, so in production builds without asserts an overflow could go undetected.
